Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH): Share of the population using safely managed drinking water sources
column3: Safely managed drinking water is water from an improved water source which is located on premises, available when needed and free from contamination.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH): Share of the population using basic drinking water services
column3: Basic drinking water is water from an improved source, where the collection time is not more than 30 minutes for a roundtrip.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH): Share of the population using limited drinking water services
column3: Limited drinking water is water from an improved source, where the collection time exceeds 30 minutes for a roundtrip.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH): Share of the population using unimproved drinking water sources
column3: An unimproved drinking water source is water from an unprotected dug well or unprotected spring.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH): Share of the population not using a drinking water facility
column3: Not using a drinking water facility means people rely on surface water: directly from a river, dam, lake, pond, stream, canal or irrigation canal.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH): Share of the population using improved drinking water sources
column3: Improved drinking water sources are those that have the potential to deliver safe water. They include piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, rainwater, and packaged or delivered water.

column3: Safely managed drinking water is water from an improved water source which is located on premises, available when needed and free from contamination.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH): Share of the population using safely managed sanitation services
column3: Safely managed sanitation means improved facilities which are not shared with other households and where excreta are safely disposed on-site or transported and treated off-site.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH): Share of the population using basic sanitation services
column3: Basic sanitation is improved facilities which are not shared with other households.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH): Share of the population using limited sanitation services
column3: Limited sanitation is improved facilities shared between two or more households.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH): Share of the population using unimproved sanitation facilities
column3: Unimproved sanitation is the use of pit latrines without a slab or platform, hanging latrines or bucket latrines.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH): Share of the population not using sanitation facilities
column3: Not using sanitation facilities means that people practice open defecation. Open defecation is the disposal of human faeces in fields, forests, bushes, open bodies of water, beaches and other open spaces or with solid waste.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH): Share of the population using improved sanitation facilities
column3: Improved sanitation facilities are designed to hygienically separate excreta from human contact. They include flush to piped sewer system, septic tanks or pit latrines; ventilated improved pit latrines, composting toilets or pit latrines with slabs.

column3: No handwashing facility is available on the premises.

column12: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column15: Safely managed sanitation is improved facilities which are not shared with other households and where excreta are safely disposed in situ or transported and treated off-site.\nImproved sanitation facilities are designed to hygienically separate excreta from human contact. They include flush to piped sewer system, septic tanks or pit latrines; ventilated improved pit latrines, composting toilets or pit latrines with slabs.

column3: Number with access to basic handwashing facilities
column10: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column12: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column15: Basic handwashing facilities are facilities on premises with soap and water.

column3: Number with access to limited handwashing facilities
column10: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column12: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column15: Limited handwashing facilities are facilities on premises without soap and water.

column3: Number with no handwashing facilities
column10: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column12: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column15: No handwashing facility is available on the premises.
